The text syle of tooltip's floating layer.

data.tooltip.textStyle.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

data.tooltip.textStyle.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.tooltip.textStyle.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.tooltip.textStyle.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

data.tooltip.textStyle.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

data.tooltip.extraCssText.desc:
NoticeÔºöseries.data.tooltip only works when tooltip.trigger is 'item'.

Extra CSS style for floating layer. The following is an example for adding shadow.

extraCssText: 'box-shadow: 0 0 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);'

links.desc:
Relational data between nodes. Example:

links: [{
    source: 'n1',
    target: 'n2'
}, {
    source: 'n2',
    target: 'n3'
}]

links.source.desc: A string representing the name of source node on edge. Can also be a number representing the node index.

links.target.desc: A string representing the name of target node on edge. Can also be a number representing node index.

links.value.desc: value of edge, can be mapped to edge length in force graph.

links.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

links.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

links.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

links.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

links.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

links.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

links.lineStyle.curveness.desc: The curveness of edge, supporting values from 0 to 1. The curveness will be larger as the value becomes lager.

links.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

links.label.align.desc:

links.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

links.label.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

links.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

links.emphasis.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

links.emphasis.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

links.emphasis.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

links.emphasis.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

links.emphasis.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

links.emphasis.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

links.emphasis.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

links.symbol.desc: Symbol of edge ends. Can be an array with two item to specify two ends, or a string specifies both ends.

links.symbolSize.desc: Symbol size of edge ends. Can be an array with two item to specify two ends, or a string specifies both ends.

links.ignoreForceLayout.desc:
Since v4.5.0

Prevent this edge from force layout calculating.

markPoint.symbol.desc:
Symbol of mark point.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

If symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => string

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

markPoint.symbolSize.desc:
mark point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

markPoint.symbolRotate.desc:
Rotate degree of mark point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

If rotation of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

Callback is supported since 4.8.0 .

markPoint.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markPoint.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of mark point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markPoint.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

markPoint.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'„ÄÅ'insideRight').

See: label position.

markPoint.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

markPoint.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markPoint.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example:

    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markPoint.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

markPoint.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markPoint.label.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.label.height.desc:

markPoint.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

markPoint.label.emphasis.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

markPoint.label.emphasis.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'„ÄÅ'insideRight').

See: label position.

markPoint.label.emphasis.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

markPoint.label.emphasis.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markPoint.label.emphasis.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

markPoint.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

markPoint.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderType.desc: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markPoint.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.data.desc:
Data array for mark points, each of which is an object. Here are some ways to assign mark point position.

  1. Assign coordinate according to container with x, y attribute, in which pixel values and percentage are supported.

  2. Assign coordinate position with coord attribute, in which 'min', 'max', 'average' are supported for each dimension.

  3. Use type attribute to mark the maximum and minimum values in the series, in which valueIndex or valueDim can be used to assign the dimension.

When multiple attributes exist, priority is as the above order.

For example: 

data: [
    {
        name: 'maximum',
        type: 'max'
    }, 
    {
        name: 'coordinate',
        coord: [10, 20]
    }, {
        name: 'fixed x position',
        yAxis: 10,
        x: '90%'
    }, 
    {
        name: 'screen coordinate',
        x: 100,
        y: 100
    }
]

markPoint.data.type.desc:
Special label types, are used to label maximum value, minimum value and so on.

Options are:

  • 'min' maximum value.
  • 'max' minimum value.
  • 'average' average value.

markPoint.data.valueIndex.desc: Available when using type it is used to assign maximum value and minimum value in dimensions, it could be 0 (xAxis, radiusAxis), 1 (yAxis, angleAxis), and use the first value axis dimension by default.

markPoint.data.valueDim.desc: Works only when type is assigned. It is used to state the dimension used to calculate maximum value or minimum value. It may be the direct name of a dimension, like x, or angle for line charts, or open, or close for candlestick charts.

markPoint.data.coord.desc:
Coordinates of the starting point or ending point, whose format depends on the coordinate of the series. It can be x, and y for rectangular coordinates, or radius, and angle for polar coordinates.

Notice: For axis with axis.type 'category':

  • If coord value is number, it represents index of axis.data.
  • If coord value is string, it represents concrete value in axis.data. Please notice that in this case xAxis.data must not be written as [number, number, ...], but can only be written [string, string, ...]. Otherwise it is not able to be located by markPoint / markLine.

For example:

{
    xAxis: {
        type: 'category',
        data: ['5', '6', '9', '13', '19', '33']
        // As mentioned above, data should not be [5, 6, 9, 13, 19, 33] here.
    },
    series: {
        type: 'line',
        data: [11, 22, 33, 44, 55, 66],
        markPoint: { // markLine is in the same way.
            data: [{
                coord: [5, 33.4], // The number 5 represents xAxis.data[5], that is, '33'.
                // coord: ['5', 33.4] // The string '5' represents the '5' in xAxis.data.
            }]
        }
    }
}

markPoint.data.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.symbol.desc:
Symbol of mark point.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

markPoint.data.symbolSize.desc: mark point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markPoint.data.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of mark point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markPoint.data.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markPoint.data.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of mark point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

markPoint.data.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.borderType.desc: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markPoint.data.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.emphasis.color.desc:
color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {

    }],

}

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.
Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.

markPoint.data.itemStyle.emphasis.shadow.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

}

markPoint.data.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

markPoint.data.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'„ÄÅ'insideRight').

See: label position.

markPoint.data.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

markPoint.data.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markPoint.data.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.data.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

markPoint.data.label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

markPoint.data.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

markPoint.data.label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.data.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.data.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markPoint.data.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

markPoint.data.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markPoint.data.label.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.data.label.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.data.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.data.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

markPoint.data.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markPoint.data.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

    }
}

Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Border width of the text fragment.
Border radius of the text fragment.

Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.
Shadow color of the text block.
Show blur of the text block.
Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Storke line width of the text.
Shadow color of the text itself.
Shadow blue of the text itself.
Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markPoint.animationThreshold.desc: Whether to set graphic number threshold to animation. Animation will be disabled when graphic number is larger than threshold.

markPoint.animationDuration.desc:
Duration of the first animation, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effect:

animationDuration: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

markPoint.animationEasing.desc: Easing method used for the first animation. Varied easing effects can be found at easing effect example.

markPoint.animationDelay.desc:
Delay before updating the first animation, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effect.

For example:

animationDelay: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

See this example for more information.

markPoint.animationDurationUpdate.desc:
Time for animation to complete, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effect:

animationDurationUpdate: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

markPoint.animationDelayUpdate.desc:
Delay before updating animation, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effects.

For example:

animationDelayUpdate: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

See this example for more information.

prefix

markLine.desc: Use a line in the chart to illustrate.

markLine.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markLine.symbol.desc: Symbol type at the two ends of the mark line. It can be an array for two ends, or assigned seperately. See data.symbol for more format information.

markLine.symbolSize.desc:
Symbol size at the two ends of the mark line. It can be an array for two ends, or assigned seperately.

Attention: You cannot assgin width and height seperately as normal symbolSize.

markLine.precision.desc: Precision of marking line value, which is useful when displaying average value mark line.

markLine.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:

  • 'start' starting point of the line.
  • 'middle' middle point of the line.
  • 'end' ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'.

'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with label.distance.

markLine.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {d}: the percent.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {d}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

markLine.label.emphasis.position.desc:

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'.

'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart.

markLine.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

markLine.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markLine.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.lineStyle.emphasis.color.desc:
Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {

    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

markLine.lineStyle.emphasis.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markLine.lineStyle.emphasis.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markLine.lineStyle.emphasis.shadowOffset.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.lineStyle.emphasis.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.desc:
Data array of marking line. Every array item can be an array of one or two values, representing starting and ending point of the line, and every item is an object. Here are several ways to assign the positions of starting and ending point.

  1. Assign coordinate according to container with x, y attribute, in which pixel values and percentage are supported.

  2. Assign coordinate position with coord attribute, in which 'min', 'max', 'average' are supported for each dimension.

  3. Use type attribute to mark the maximum and minimum values in the series, in which valueIndex or valueDim can be used to assign the dimension.

  4. You may also create a mark line in Cartesian coordinate at a specific position in X or Y axis by assigning xAxis or yAxis. See scatter-weight for example.

When multiple attributes exist, priority is as the above order.

You may also set the type of mark line through type, stating whether it is for the maximum value or average value. Likewise, dimensions can be assigned through valueIndex.

data: [
    {
        name: 'average line',
        // 'average', 'min', and 'max' are supported
        type: 'average'
    },
    {
        name: 'Horizontal line with Y value at 100',
        yAxis: 100
    },
    [
        {
            // Use the same name with starting and ending point
            name: 'Minimum to Maximum',
            type: 'min'
        },
        {
            type: 'max'
        }
    ],
    [
        {
            name: 'Markline between two points',
            coord: [10, 20]
        },
        {
            coord: [20, 30]
        }
    ], [{
        // Mark line with a fixed X position in starting point. This is used to generate an arrow pointing to maximum line.
        yAxis: 'max',
        x: '90%'
    }, {
        type: 'max'
    }],
    [
        {
            name: 'Mark line between two points',
            x: 100,
            y: 100
        },
        {
            x: 500,
            y: 200
        }
    ]
]

markLine.data.0.type.desc:
Special label types, are used to label maximum value, minimum value and so on.

Options are:

  • 'min' minimum value.
  • 'max' maximum value.
  • 'average' average value.
  • 'median' median value.

markLine.data.0.valueIndex.desc: Works only when type is assigned. It is used to state the dimension used to calculate maximum value or minimum value. It may be 0 (for xAxis, or radiusAxis), or 1 (for yAxis, or angleAxis). Dimension of the first numeric axis is used by default.

markLine.data.0.valueDim.desc: Works only when type is assigned. It is used to state the dimension used to calculate maximum value or minimum value. It may be the direct name of a dimension, like x, or angle for line charts, or open, or close for candlestick charts.

markLine.data.0.coord.desc:
Coordinates of the starting point or ending point, whose format depends on the coordinate of the series. It can be x, and y for rectangular coordinates, or radius, and angle for polar coordinates.

Notice: For axis with axis.type 'category':

  • If coord value is number, it represents index of axis.data.
  • If coord value is string, it represents concrete value in axis.data. Please notice that in this case xAxis.data must not be written as [number, number, ...], but can only be written [string, string, ...]. Otherwise it is not able to be located by markPoint / markLine.

For example:

{
    xAxis: {
        type: 'category',
        data: ['5', '6', '9', '13', '19', '33']
        // As mentioned above, data should not be [5, 6, 9, 13, 19, 33] here.
    },
    series: {
        type: 'line',
        data: [11, 22, 33, 44, 55, 66],
        markPoint: { // markLine is in the same way.
            data: [{
                coord: [5, 33.4], // The number 5 represents xAxis.data[5], that is, '33'.
                // coord: ['5', 33.4] // The string '5' represents the '5' in xAxis.data.
            }]
        }
    }
}

markLine.data.0.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.0.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.symbol.desc:
Symbol of starting point.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

markLine.data.0.symbolSize.desc: starting point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markLine.data.0.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of starting point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.0.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markLine.data.0.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of starting point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.desc: Line style of this data item, which will be merged with lineStyle of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.emphasis.shado.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}
Shadow color. Support same format as color.
Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.emphasis.opaci.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.emphasis.curve.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.0.label.desc: Label of this data item, which will be merged with label of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.0.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:

  • 'start' starting point of the line.
  • 'middle' middle point of the line.
  • 'end' ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'.

'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with label.distance.

markLine.data.0.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.data.0.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {d}: the percent.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {d}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.color.desc:

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.

    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {

    }],

}

}

    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

markLine.data.1.type.desc:
Special label types, are used to label maximum value, minimum value and so on.

Options are:

  • 'min' minimum value.
  • 'max' maximum value.
  • 'average' average value.
  • 'median' median value.

markLine.data.1.valueIndex.desc: Works only when type is assigned. It is used to state the dimension used to calculate maximum value or minimum value. It may be 0 (for xAxis, or radiusAxis), or 1 (for yAxis, or angleAxis). Dimension of the first numeric axis is used by default.

markLine.data.1.valueDim.desc: Works only when type is assigned. It is used to state the dimension used to calculate maximum value or minimum value. It may be the direct name of a dimension, like x, or angle for line charts, or open, or close for candlestick charts.

markLine.data.1.coord.desc:
Coordinates of the starting point or ending point, whose format depends on the coordinate of the series. It can be x, and y for rectangular coordinates, or radius, and angle for polar coordinates.

Notice: For axis with axis.type 'category':

  • If coord value is number, it represents index of axis.data.
  • If coord value is string, it represents concrete value in axis.data. Please notice that in this case xAxis.data must not be written as [number, number, ...], but can only be written [string, string, ...]. Otherwise it is not able to be located by markPoint / markLine.

For example:

{
    xAxis: {
        type: 'category',
        data: ['5', '6', '9', '13', '19', '33']
        // As mentioned above, data should not be [5, 6, 9, 13, 19, 33] here.
    },
    series: {
        type: 'line',
        data: [11, 22, 33, 44, 55, 66],
        markPoint: { // markLine is in the same way.
            data: [{
                coord: [5, 33.4], // The number 5 represents xAxis.data[5], that is, '33'.
                // coord: ['5', 33.4] // The string '5' represents the '5' in xAxis.data.
            }]
        }
    }
}

markLine.data.1.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.1.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.symbol.desc:
Symbol of ending point.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

markLine.data.1.symbolSize.desc: ending point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markLine.data.1.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of ending point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.1.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markLine.data.1.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of ending point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.desc: Line style of this data item, which will be merged with lineStyle of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.

    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}

    }],
    global: false // false by default
}

    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.
